comment._content: Like a display of lovely all-in-one corsets.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] you mention PIG carcasses but these are mixed, mutton, beef and pork.  This is not that common as pork butchery was treated as a separate trade entirely, I suspect that this was due to the fears of infection that pork was supposed to present.  It is not without good reason that Kosher and Hallal laws proscribe the eating of pork, in those days in hot climates it could be problematic.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Really thought they were just pigs! Added notes above querying mutton and beef - will you check the carcasses out for me? See, I really know how to show someone a good time...  :D

comment.author: 45908178@N03
comment._content: Beautiful document of History...these are so precious, to be able to stare at the past and understand through an other vision, other then words.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03]  You must be one of these Veggietarians?  I put notes on the Mutton, Beef and Pork above to guide the unenlightened!  Pork will retain its skin as there is very little market for it as a source of leather or hide.  It is very like the human epidermis and in fact pork has many similarities to human flesh.  Police body search dogs are trained using pork and pork bones as the odour is very similar to human flesh and bones! (Just a bit of useless information)

comment.author: 66277514@N00
comment._content: Hi folks.  I came into this discussion late, but I note that the photo of the home and crown store shows brick to their right, while the butcher shop does not hve brick on that edge, thus dating the construction of Mr Morgan's store front to after 1910.
